Parameters

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats module

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats.ann_estimated_sharpe_ratio(returns=None, periods=261, *, sr=None)

Calculate the annualized estimated sharpe ratio (risk_free=0). :param returns: :type returns: np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame :param periods: How many items in returns complete a Year.

If returns are daily: 261, weekly: 52, monthly: 12, …

Parameters

sr (float, np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame) – Sharpe ratio to be annualized, it’s frequency must be coherent with periods

Return type

float, pd.Series

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats.deflated_sharpe_ratio(trials_returns=None, returns_selected=None, expected_mean_sr=0.0, *, expected_max_sr=None)

Calculate the Deflated Sharpe Ratio (PSR). :param trials_returns: All trials returns, not only the independent trials. :type trials_returns: pd.DataFrame :param returns_selected: :type returns_selected: pd.Series :param expected_mean_sr: Expected mean SR, usually 0. We assume that random strategies will have a mean SR of 0,

expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

Parameters

expected_max_sr (float) – The expected maximum sharpe ratio expected after running all the trials, expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

Return type

float

Notes

DFS = PSR(SR⁰) = probability that SR^ > SR⁰ SR^ = sharpe ratio estimated with returns, or sr SR⁰ = max_expected_sr https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2460551

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats.estimated_sharpe_ratio(returns)

Calculate the estimated sharpe ratio (risk_free=0). :param returns: :type returns: np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame

Return type

float, pd.Series

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats.estimated_sharpe_ratio_stdev(returns=None, *, n=None, skew=None, kurtosis=None, sr=None)

Calculate the standard deviation of the sharpe ratio estimation. :param returns: If no returns are passed it is mandatory to pass the other 4 parameters. :type returns: np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame :param n: Number of returns samples used for calculating skew, kurtosis and sr. :type n: int :param skew: The third moment expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

`skew`=0 for normal returns.

Parameters

  • kurtosis (float, np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame) – The fourth moment expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters. `kurtosis`=3 for normal returns.

  • sr (float, np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame) – Sharpe ratio expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

Return type

float, pd.Series

Notes

This formula generalizes for both normal and non-normal returns. https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1821643

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats.expected_maximum_sr(trials_returns=None, expected_mean_sr=0.0, *, independent_trials=None, trials_sr_std=None)

Compute the expected maximum Sharpe ratio (Analytically)

Parameters

  • trials_returns (pd.DataFrame) – All trials returns, not only the independent trials.

  • expected_mean_sr (float) – Expected mean SR, usually 0. We assume that random startegies will have a mean SR of 0, expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

  • independent_trials (int) – Number of independent trials, must be between 1 and trials_returns.shape[1]

  • trials_sr_std (float) – Standard deviation fo the Estimated sharpe ratios of all trials, expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

Return type

float

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats.min_track_record_length(returns=None, sr_benchmark=0.0, prob=0.95, *, n=None, sr=None, sr_std=None)

Calculate the MIn Track Record Length (minTRL). :param returns: If no returns are passed it is mandatory to pass a sr and sr_std. :type returns: np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame :param sr_benchmark: Benchmark sharpe ratio expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

By default set to zero (comparing against no investment skill).

Parameters

  • prob (float) – Confidence level used for calculating the minTRL. Between 0 and 1, by default=0.95

  • n (int) – Number of returns samples used for calculating sr and sr_std.

  • sr (float, np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame) – Sharpe ratio expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

  • sr_std (float, np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame) – Standard deviation fo the Estimated sharpe ratio, expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

Return type

float, pd.Series

Notes

minTRL = minimum of returns/samples needed (with same SR and SR_STD) to accomplish a PSR(SR*) > prob PSR(SR*) = probability that SR^ > SR* SR^ = sharpe ratio estimated with returns, or sr SR* = sr_benchmark https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1821643

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats.num_independent_trials(trials_returns=None, *, m=None, p=None)

Calculate the number of independent trials.

Parameters

  • trials_returns (pd.DataFrame) – All trials returns, not only the independent trials.

  • m (int) – Number of total trials.

  • p (float) – Average correlation between all the trials.

Return type

int

EvaluationLayer.SharpeStats.probabilistic_sharpe_ratio(returns=None, sr_benchmark=0.0, *, sr=None, sr_std=None)

Calculate the Probabilistic Sharpe Ratio (PSR). :param returns: If no returns are passed it is mandatory to pass a sr and sr_std. :type returns: np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame :param sr_benchmark: Benchmark sharpe ratio expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

By default set to zero (comparing against no investment skill).

Parameters

  • sr (float, np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame) – Sharpe ratio expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

  • sr_std (float, np.array, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame) – Standard deviation fo the Estimated sharpe ratio, expressed in the same frequency as the other parameters.

Return type

float, pd.Series

Notes

PSR(SR*) = probability that SR^ > SR* SR^ = sharpe ratio estimated with returns, or sr SR* = sr_benchmark https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1821643
